title: What Does L Mean when Texting? Meaning, Usage, & More

steps.title: Most people drop a :L to convey that theyâ€™re speechless.
steps.content: Most people drop a :L to convey that theyâ€™re speechless. Similar to the ğŸ˜ (neutral face) emoji, a :L kind of looks like someone staring blankly. Use :L when you want to show someone you donâ€™t have a reaction. Just FYI, this emoticon usually implies that youâ€™re being a touch playful. [1] X Research source For example: Them: â€œI just put mayo on a hot dog and itâ€™sâ€¦not good.â€ You: â€œ:L what exactly were you expecting?â€

steps.title: Some people use :L to mean â€œIâ€™m laughing.â€
steps.content: Some people use :L to mean â€œIâ€™m laughing.â€ While less popular than the blank-face version of the emoticon, many people use :L as a substitution for lol. The colon represents eyes, and the L is just short for laughing. As an example: Them: â€œHow do you organize a party for an astronaut? You planet.â€ You: â€œ:L okay that oneâ€™s pretty good.â€

steps.title: Drop a :L if you want to convey youâ€™re playfully unimpressed.
steps.content: Drop a :L if you want to convey youâ€™re playfully unimpressed. If you want to throw a little side eye like youâ€™re not buying what someone is selling, :L is a fun way to do it. Itâ€™s an expressive way to show youâ€™re expressionless! As an example: Them: â€œI think I might have lost my mattressâ€¦â€ You: â€œ:L you did what nowâ€¦â€

steps.title: Use :L the same way youâ€™d use â€œlolâ€ to show youâ€™re laughing.
steps.content: Use :L the same way youâ€™d use â€œlolâ€ to show youâ€™re laughing. Instead of throwing a ğŸ˜‚ or lol out in reaction to a funny comment, use :L to demonstrate that you find something funny. For example: Them: â€œIâ€™m so bored of Mr. Greenâ€™s science class that I might write my final paper on sleep paralysis demons.â€ You: â€œIncredible :L imagine if you actually did that.â€

steps.title: L is usually short for â€œloss.â€
steps.content: L is usually short for â€œloss.â€ If you â€œtake an Lâ€ it means youâ€™re taking a loss. This can be a literal loss, as in you losing a pickup basketball game, or it can be a figurative loss, like you not getting to go to a party. For example: [2] X Research source â€œYou think youâ€™re going to beat me in Mario Kart? Iâ€™ll hand you an L any time.â€ â€œI took a major L today after school. I asked Mia out and she said no â˜¹â€ â€œIf youâ€™re ready to take this L, we can go minigolfing again whenever youâ€™d like ğŸ˜Šâ€

steps.title: Use a well-timed L to banter in a friendly competition.
steps.content: Use a well-timed L to banter in a friendly competition. Tell someone youâ€™re handing out Ls and watch the no-you-didnâ€™t oohs and ahs go flying. This is an excellent way to boost your trash talk and take it to the next level. [3] X Research source For example, you might say: â€œIf you really need an L, Iâ€™ve got you covered.â€ â€œStep to me on the basketball court and youâ€™re taking an L homeâ€”I guarantee it.â€ â€œNo way Tupac was better than Biggie. If those two battled, Pac would take the L any day.â€

steps.title: Drop an L to downplay a genuine loss you experienced.
steps.content: Drop an L to downplay a genuine loss you experienced. Saying you â€œtook an Lâ€ instead of simply explaining something bad that happened to you is a good way to subtly suggest that you arenâ€™t all that shook up about it. You could say: â€œI definitely took an L on that math exam. No way I donâ€™t end up in summer school.â€ â€œSo, I donâ€™t think Tony wants to go out with me again :/ guess Iâ€™m taking another dating L.â€ â€œMy brother didnâ€™t get into Wisconsin University. Heâ€™s not taking the L particularly well.â€

steps.title: L and C is short for â€œlike and commentâ€ on Instagram, YouTube, and TikTok.
steps.content: L and C is short for â€œlike and commentâ€ on Instagram, YouTube, and TikTok. Liking and commenting posts or videos on YouTube, Instagram, or TikTok will give the author a boost in visibility on all these platforms. [4] X Research source Since â€œmake sure you guys like, comment, and subscribeâ€ is a pretty drawn out way of communicating that, authors on both platforms will often just shorten it to â€œL & C.â€ [5] X Research source A post might have description including: â€œL and C pls. It really helps out.â€ â€œL & C for more great content.â€ â€œPleas L, C, and S!â€

steps.title: L + ratio is a way to sarcastically mock people on social media.
steps.content: L + ratio is a way to sarcastically mock people on social media. Originating on Twitter, a â€œratioâ€ refers to a post where the ratio between likes and replies is really lopsided towards the replies. The â€œLâ€ component of the equation is short for â€œloss.â€ Take them together, and the implication here is that someone has said something extremely unpopular. People use it ironically, but itâ€™s probably a genuine put down if theyâ€™re replying to a comment that actually has been ratioed. [6] X Research source For example, you could say: â€œYouâ€™re going to get L + ratioed if you donâ€™t delete this.â€ â€œI hate to do it, but L + ratio. This is a terrible take.â€ â€œL + ratio + unsubscribed + go homeâ€

steps.title: Left
steps.content: Left If someone is giving directions or they use an L and R in the same sentence, theyâ€™re probably using L as a shorthand for left. For example, someone might write: â€œTake an L at Harbor St. Weâ€™re on the corner.â€ â€œIf someone canâ€™t figure out the difference between L and R, they probably shouldnâ€™t be driving.â€

steps.title: Liter
steps.content: Liter L is the official shorthand for liter, which is the metric unit of measurement for volume (1 L is equivalent to 0.26 US gallons, in case youâ€™re curious). If it looks like someone is sharing a measurement, the L is almost certainly short for liter. [7] X Research source Someone might say: â€œCan you grab a 2 L of Pepsi on your way home?â€ â€œJason went wild last night. He drank like 8 L of ale before stumbling home.â€

steps.title: 50 (Roman numeral)
steps.content: 50 (Roman numeral) L is the Roman numeral for 50. Youâ€™re unlikely to encounter this one over text, but youâ€™ll occasionally run into this one in history books or at museums. For example, LI = 51 since L is 50 and I is 1. [8] X Research source
